title: Mont Maudit
text:
Mont Maudit (4,465 m) is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> in the <a href="Mont%20Blanc%20massif">Mont Blanc massif</a> in <a href="France">France</a> and <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. The <a href="French%20%28language%29">French</a> name literally means "Cursed Mountain". Until the end of the 18th century, <a href="Mont%20Blanc">Mont Blanc</a> and its satellite peaks were collectively known in French as the "Montagne Maudite".
Climbing history.
The <a href="first%20ascent">first ascent</a> of Mont Maudit was by a <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> party comprising <a href="Sir%20Henry%20King%2C%201st%20Baronet">Henry Seymour King</a> and the lawyer/diplomat William Edward Davidson with guides Johann Jaun and Johann von Bergen on 12 September 1878. The route they took was via the south ridge, during an ascent of Mont Blanc by the Corridor route.
The southern side of the mountain is considerably steeper than the gentle snow slopes of the northern side and features the well-known southeast or Frontier ridge (also known as the Kuffner ridge, D). This route was first climbed by <a href="Moriz%20von%20Kuffner">Moriz von Kuffner</a> with guides <a href="Alexander%20Burgener">Alexander Burgener</a> and Josef Furrer from 2–4 July 1887. <a href="George%20Mallory">George Mallory</a>, in a party led by <a href="Robert%20Lock%20Graham%20Irving">R. L. G. Irving</a>, made the third ascent of the route in 1911. Ascents of the ridge start from the hut on the Col du Trident and take at least seven to eight hours.
2012 avalanche.
On 12 July 2012, at least nine climbers—three from the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> (including Roger Payne, a mountain guide and former general secretary of the <a href="British%20Mountaineering%20Council">British Mountaineering Council</a>), two from <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, two from <a href="Germany">Germany</a>, and two from <a href="Spain">Spain</a>—were killed by an avalanche as they attempted a dawn ascent of the mountain from the <a href="Refuge%20des%20Cosmiques">Refuge des Cosmiques</a>. Nine others were injured and flown to hospital. The avalanche struck at 5 am, as the climbers began their climb up one of the most popular, but dangerous, routes up the mountain. Éric Fournier, the mayor of <a href="Chamonix">Chamonix–Mont Blanc</a>, described the snowslide as one of the deadliest in recent years. "There was no weather bulletin giving any avalanche warning," he claimed.
